report:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  History of renal cell carcinoma currently on drug trial, now with
 sepsis related to pneumonia.  
 
 COMPARISON:  Comparison is made with chest radiographs from ___ and
 ___.  
 
 FINDINGS:
 
 PA lateral images of the chest.  
 
 Lungs are moderately well-expanded.  Bibasilar opacities have increased in the
 interval, consistent with worsening multifocal pneumonia.  The upper lungs are
 clear.  Small bilateral pleural effusions are seen.  No pneumothorax is seen. 
 Hilar adenopathy is more pronounced than in ___ but similar to more
 recent exams.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unremarkable.  
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 Increased bibasilar opacities consistent with worsening multifocal pneumonia.
name: pneumonia

 PORTABLE CHEST, ___

 terminates in the distal left brachiocephalic vein.  Nasogastric tube
 terminates below the diaphragm.  Heart size is normal.  Bilateral multifocal
 areas of consolidation show a slight interval improvement, and likely
 represent improving multifocal pneumonia.  Coexisting linear atelectasis is
 present in the left mid lung region.

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: ___M with sob  // ?pna, ? pl eff
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Frontal lateral views of the chest.
 
 COMPARISON:  Correlation made to CT abdomen pelvis from ___.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 There are moderate bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left. 
 Associated atelectasis is noted in noting that superimposed infection
 particularly at the right base cannot be excluded.  Coarse interstitial
 markings are seen superiorly, likely in part due to emphysema.  Cardiac
 silhouette cannot be adequately assessed.  No acute osseous abnormality.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Moderate bilateral pleural effusions and associated atelectasis.  More dense
 consolidation at the right lung base raises possibility of superimposed
 infection.
label_text:
More dense
 consolidation at the right lung base raises possibility of superimposed
 infection.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  Chest radiographs.
 
 INDICATION:  Hypotension.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest, PA and lateral.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 The cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours appear unchanged.  There is a
 persistent diffuse mild interstitial abnormality.  This appearance suggests
 mild vascular pulmonary edema but is less striking than on the prior
 radiographs.  In addition a lingular opacity is seen in two views but better
 depicted on the frontal view.  There is no definite pleural effusion or
 pneumothorax.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 1.  Focal opacity in the lingula.  This could be seen with pneumonia but is
 also a common site for atelectasis. Correlation with clinical presentation and
 consideration of short-term follow-up radiographs is suggested.
 
 2.  Findings suggesting mild pulmonary edema.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Known lung carcinoma, now with cough for seven days and low-grade
 temperature with increased shortness of breath.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Two views of the chest.
 
 COMPARISON:  Multiple prior examinations, the most recent radiographs dated
 ___ and review of PET-CT dated ___.
 
 FINDINGS AND IMPRESSION:  Loculated pleural effusion is increased with
 increased pleural thickening at the left apex and along the left mediastinal
 contour.  There remains dense opacification at the left base; however, there
 is now a retrocardiac air fluid level suggestive of necrosis/cavitation in the
 lung mass.  There is new patchy opacity with air bronchograms extending from
 the left hilum throughout the left lung which has the appearance of infection.
 No pneumothorax is present.  The right lung is clear.  Surgical clips are
 noted along the right lateral chest wall.
label_text:
air bronchograms extending from
 the left hilum throughout the left lung which has the appearance of infection.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Chest pain.
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest CTA from the same day.
 
 FINDINGS:  There are bilateral basal opacities with the most confluent at the
 left base suggestive of multifocal pneumonia.  Otherwise, cardiomediastinal
 silhouette appears moderately enlarged.  There is no pneumothorax or pleural
 effusion. Small lung nodules in the upper lobes seen in concurrent CT are
 below the resolution of this CXR.
 
 IMPRESSION:  Findings suggestive of multifocal pneumonia, worst in the left
 lower lobe, and better delineated on the dedicated chest CTA.  Follow up in
 six weeks is recommended to ensure resolution.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  Chest radiograph
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___F with sepsis; line comfirmation  // L CVL placement;
 infiltrate?
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP upright radiograph view of the chest.
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph dated ___.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 A left sided Port-A-Cath tip projects just to the right of midline a over the
 expected region of the mid to upper SVC.  Left lower lobe dense consolidation
 is perhaps slightly more conspicuous particularly in the perihilar region
 compared to the prior exam - this likely reflects a combination of infection
 in the setting of sepsis, atelectasis, as well as a small pleural effusion. 
 New heterogeneous right lower lobe consolidation is likely pneumonia.  Mild
 interstitial edema is improved since ___.  Probable mild cardiomegaly
 is overall similar.  No pneumothorax.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 1.  Catheter tip projects over the expected region of the mid to upper SVC.
 2.  Bibasilar pneumonia increased since ___.
 3.  Persistent small left pleural effusion and atelectasis.
 4.  Mild interstitial edema, improved.
name: pneumonia

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old male with type 2 diabetes, vascular dementia,
 presents with fever and cough.
 
 COMPARISON:  PA and lateral radiographs of the chest ___.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral chest radiographs.
 
 FINDINGS:  There has been interval improvement in lung volumes and aeration,
 however, previously seen basilar opacities are more prominent, right greater
 than left, is concerning for pneumonia.  There are no other areas of
 consolidation concerning for infection.  Pleural surfaces are within normal
 limits.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged.  Patient is status post
 sternotomy with sternotomy wires seen in alignment. No evidence of heart
 failure.
 
 IMPRESSION:  Right basilar opacity consistent with infection.  Left basilar
 opacity may represent a second focus of infection.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST RADIOGRAPH
 
 INDICATION:  Hypoxia.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest, AP portable.
 
 COMPARISON:  Two days earlier.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 The patient is status post coronary artery bypass graft surgery. There are
 dishiscences among several sternal wires which appear unchanged. There is
 bilateral new moderate perihilar vascular engorgement and diffuse mild
 pulmonary edema in addition to a small pleural effusion on the right. The left
 lower lung is more generally opacified, markedly increased, and probably
 including a pleural effusion.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 1.  Findings suggesting pulmonary edema including pleural effusions.
 
 2.  Focal opacity at the left lung base suggesting pneumonia, although
 atelectasis possible, in addition to suspected pleural effusion.
label_text: Focal opacity at the left lung base suggesting pneumonia,
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Respiratory failure with intubation.
 
 FINDINGS:  In comparison with the study of earlier in this date, there has
 been placement of an endotracheal tube with its tip approximately 4.7 cm above
 the carina.  Nasogastric tube extends to the stomach, though the sidehole is
 above the esophagogastric junction.  Left subclavian catheter tip extends to
 the mid-to-lower portion of the SVC.  No evidence of pneumothorax.
 
 There is increased opacification again at the right base silhouetting the
 hemidiaphragm, consistent with a combination of layering effusion and
 compressive atelectasis at the base.  Prominent changes are seen on the left. 
 In the appropriate clinical setting, aspiration or even infectious pneumonia
 would have to be considered.
label_text: ncreased opacification again at the right base
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL INDICATION:  Dyspnea.  Evaluate for pneumonia and congestive heart
 failure.
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph ___.
 
 PORTABLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST:  The lung volumes are low which causes
 crowding of the bronchovascular structures.  There is a left retrocardiac
 opacity which may represent atelectasis or infection.  No large pleural
 effusion or pneumothorax is identified.  Mild pulmonary edema appears
 relatively unchanged since ___.  Cardiomegaly and calcification
 of the aortic knob is also relatively unchanged.  A pacer with leads in the
 right atrium and right ventricle is redemonstrated.  There is no free air
 beneath the right hemidiaphragm.
 
 IMPRESSION:  Retrocardiac opacity is incompletely assessed and could represent
 atelectasis and or pneumonia. Please refer to subsequent CTA chest results for
 further details.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH
 
 INDICATION:  Cough and fever, evaluation for pneumonia.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___.
 
 FINDINGS:  As compared to the previous radiograph, there now is an obvious
 parenchymal opacity in the left lower lobe that is better seen on the lateral
 than on the frontal radiograph.  The opacity shows air bronchograms and has a
 slightly retractile character, reflected by the partial elevation of the left
 hemidiaphragm in its posterior portion.  There also is a small associated
 plate-like atelectasis.  In light of the clinical history, the presence of
 pneumonia is likely.
 
 No other lung parenchymal changes.  Known coronary stent.  No pleural
 effusions.  Normal size of the cardiac silhouette.
 
 At the time of dictation and observation, ___, at ___, the
 referring physician ___. ___ was paged for notification and the findings were
 discussed over the telephone.
label_text: parenchymal opacity in the left lower lobe
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  ___-year-old male with a history of strep pneumoniae bacteremia and
 pneumonia now intubated.  Question ET tube placement and disease progression.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___.
 
 FINDINGS:  The ET tube terminates 3.5 cm above the carina.  A right
 transjugular central venous catheter has tip in the lower SVC.  There is
 moderate cardiomegaly, which is accentuated by AP technique.  There is
 progressive increase in dense consolidation in the right upper lobe and also
 increased opacities in the left perihilar region and left lower lobe,
 consistent with worsening multifocal pneumonia.  The left lung is reasonably
 aerated, with streaky subsegmental atelectasis in the left lower lobe.  There
 is likely a small right pleural effusion.
  
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 1. Appropriate ET tube positioning.  
 2. Interval progression of multifocal pneumonia.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  ___-year-old female with aspiration, question interval change.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___ and ___.
 
 FINDINGS:  Portable frontal chest radiograph demonstrates increasing air space
 opacity in a right infrahilar location, which is compatible with given history
 of aspiration although superimposed pneumonia cannot be excluded.  There is no
 significant pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  The cardiac silhouette and
 mediastinal contours are normal.  The pulmonary vasculature is normal. There
 has been interval extubation and NG tube removal.
 
 IMPRESSION:  Increasing right infrahilar air space opacity which is compatible
 with given history of aspiration, although pneumonia cannot be excluded. The
 interval increase in the extent of the opacity weights the differential
 diagnosis towards pneumonia rather than atelectasis.
label_text:
air space
 opacity in a right infrahilar location
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old man with history of metastatic osteosarcoma with
 bilateral pleural effusion status post drainage, now with acute dyspnea, here
 to evaluate for interval change.
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph most recently performed on ___.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Portable frontal radiograph of the chest.
 
 FINDINGS:  A right Port-A-Cath is unchanged in position with the tip
 terminating at the level of the cavoatrial junction.  The cardiomediastinal
 contours are stable.  Widespread extensive air space opacities with lower lobe
 predominance are redemonstrated.  There is a moderate right pleural effusion
 silhouetting the right hemidiaphragm.  No significant left pleural effusion is
 seen with a left pleural pigtail catheter in stable position compared to the
 most recent prior study.  There is lucency at the left cardiophrenic angle
 compatible with a small left basilar pneumothorax seen on the prior chest CT
 of ___.  Lymphangitic carcinomatosis is better appreciated on
 the prior chest CT.  Overall, there is no substantial change from the most
 recent prior study.
name: pneumonia

 enlargement.  There is a persistent pleural effusion on the left, but with

report:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___F with pancreatic mass with atypical cells x___ years,
 with cough
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral
 
 COMPARISON:  None.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Heart size is normal.  Atherosclerotic calcifications are noted at the aortic
 knob.  Mediastinal and hilar contours are unremarkable.  Ill-defined focal
 opacities are seen within the right upper lobe, right lung base, and periphery
 of the left mid lung field.  Minimal blunting of the left costophrenic angle
 posteriorly suggests a trace pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax or pulmonary
 vascular congestion is present.  There are degenerative changes within the
 imaged thoracolumbar spine.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 
 1. Bilateral multifocal airspace opacities, potentially multifocal pneumonia,
 however given the patient's history of pancreatic mass, metastases are also
 within the differential diagnosis.  Comparison with prior radiographs or
 further assessment with contrast-enhanced chest CT is recommended.
 2. Small left pleural effusion.
 
 RECOMMENDATION(S):  Bilateral multifocal airspace opacities, potentially
 multifocal pneumonia, however given the patient's history of pancreatic mass,
 metastases are also within the differential diagnosis. Comparison with prior
 radiographs or further assessment with contrast-enhanced chest CT is
 recommended.
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 PA AND LATERAL CHEST OF ___
 
 COMPARISON:  Radiograph of ___, CTA of the chest of ___
 and prior chest radiographs dating back to ___.
 
 FINDINGS:  The patient is status post right upper lobe resection.  The right
 hilum appears enlarged and abnormally dense compared to the left, but is
 without change.  Immediately lateral to the right hilum is a new area of
 poorly defined opacity approximately at right eighth posterior rib level. 
 Lungs are otherwise remarkable for a persistent area of poorly defined opacity
 anteriorly in the right middle lobe projecting in the retrosternal area on the
 lateral view, and corresponding to an area of apparent scarring on ___ chest CTA.  Cardiomediastinal contours are unchanged.  Small pleural
 effusions have resolved since the prior study.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 New poorly defined right juxta-hilar opacity, possibly due to an early/focal
 pneumonia given clinical suspicion for pneumonia.  However, recurrent
 malignancy is an additional consideration, particularly considering adjacent
 persistent enlargement and increased density of the right hilum.  
 
 Management recommendation for this finding is treatment for pneumonia with
 short-term followup radiographs. However, as there is reportedly also a
 potential clinical concern for aortic dissection, an immediate chest CTA
 should be considered as a CXR is not sufficiently sensitive or specific for
 detecting or excluding this diagnosis.
label_text: poorly defined opacity approximately at right eighth posterior rib level.
name: pneumonia

 FINDINGS:  A new endotracheal tube is in satisfactory position approximately
 3.5 cm from the carina.  A nasogastric tube courses below the diaphragm with
 the tip out of the field of view.  Since the prior exam, the moderate-sized
 right pleural effusion appears slightly increased in size.  Bibasilar
 consolidations appear slightly worse, particularly on the right.  This is
 consistent with multifocal pneumonia, likely with a component of increasing
 pulmonary edeam given the rapid interval change.  There is no pneumothorax. 
 The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Satisfactory position of the endotracheal and nasogastric tubes.
 2.  Slight interval worsening of the bilateral opacities, particularly on the
 right, consistent with a combination of worsening edema and pneumonia.
 3.  Slight interval increase in the moderate sized right pleural effusion.
label_text:
Bibasilar
 consolidations appear slightly worse, particularly on the right.  This is
 consistent with multifocal pneumonia
name: pneumonia

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Right middle lobe lung mass, now status post bronchoscopy. 
 Assess for pneumothorax.
 
 COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to chest radiograph performed ___ and
 fluoroscopic chest radiograph images obtained the same day.
 
 FINDINGS:  In the region of recent bronchoscopy as evidenced by the
 fluoroscopic images obtained the same day, there is a vague 6.1 x 4.3 cm
 opacification, likely represents hemorrhage, not unexpected.  In addition,
 there is an opacification in the right infrahilar space with a suggestion of
 volume loss.  This likely represents subsegmental collapse of the right middle
 lobe.  Streaky bibasilar atelectatic changes present.  There appears to be a
 small right apical pneumothorax with the superior pleural line projecting
 immediately inferior to the posterior right third rib.  Minimal blunting of
 the bilateral costophrenic angles may represent tiny pleural effusions versus
 pleural thickening.
 
 IMPRESSION: Small right apical pneumothorax and pulmonary hemorrhage, not
 unexpected finding following bronchoscopy.
 
 ___ communicated these findings to Dr. ___ at 10:30 a.m.
 on ___ via telephone at the time of discovery.
name: pneumothorax

 ___.

 concerning for pneumonia.

 VATS bullectomy, now with chest tube removal, evaluate for pneumothorax.
 
 Comparison is made to the patient's previous study dated ___ at ___.
 
 PA and lateral views of the chest ___ at ___ are submitted.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 1.  Interval removal of the left chest tube with some residual subcutaneous
 emphysema within the lateral chest wall soft tissues.  There continue to be
 bilateral parenchymal opacities and distortion in both lungs consistent with
 known history of bullous emphysema.  On the left, there continues to be
 loculated areas of pneumothorax as well as a fluid level posteriorly, which
 represents a loculated hydropneumothorax.  More rounded opacity in the left
 mid to lower lung is also stable.  Overall, there is no significant interval
 change in appearance of the left lung.  Evaluation of the cardiac and
 mediastinal contours is challenging due to the diffuse lung disease but is
 likely stable.
name: pneumothorax

report:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old male with chest pain.  Evaluate for pneumothorax or
 congestive heart failure.
 
 COMPARISON:  None available.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral chest radiographs.
 
 FINDINGS:  The lungs are well expanded. In the right apex there is an
 irregular linear opacity without clear lung markings above this line raising
 concern for a small pneumothorax. No left sided pneumothorax is seen. Patchy
 and linear opacities are noted in the both lung bases, left worse than right,
 with associated bilateral pleural effusions, left worse than right as well. 
 Widened mediastinum is present and may be a combination of prominent fat and
 vascular structures. Enlarged cardiac silhouette may reflect cardiomegaly
 and/or pericardial effusion. Sternotomy wires and mediastinal clips are from
 prior surgery.  
 
 IMPRESSION:  
 1.  Probable small right apical pneumothorax. Repeat chest radiograph is
 recommended to exclude enlarging pneumothorax.
 2.  Bibasilar patchy and linear opacities, which may be secondary to
 atelectasis, pneumonia, or aspiration. Adjacent small pleural effusions, left
 greater than right.
 
 Item 1 of the Impression was addedd after review with the attending for which
 the ___ nurse was informed to have the findings communicated to the PCP of the
 patient on ___ at 9 am via e-mail by Dr ___.
name: pneumothorax

report:
WET READ: ___ ___ ___ 9:54 PM
Moderate-to-large bilateral pneumothoraces, small pneumomediastinum,
  significant subcutaneous gas, and free intraperitoneal air, in keeping with
  the history of duodenal perforation.  Related volume loss and atelectasis in
  the bilateral lungs.  Normal heart size.  Results were discussed with Dr.
  ___ (on-call GI fellow) and Dr. ___ ___ resident) at 950 and ___ PM
  aon ___ via telephone by Dr. ___ at the time the findings were
  discovered.
  
 WET READ VERSION #1 
 ______________________________________________________________________________
FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST, 9:14 P.M.  ON ___
 
 HISTORY:  ___-year-old woman with obstructive jaundice and duodenal perforation
 during ERCP.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 AP chest reviewed in the absence of prior chest radiographs, at 9:20 a.m., a
 following series of chest radiographs as late as 8:09 a.m. on ___:
 
 By the time this chest radiograph was officially interpreted by the staff
 radiologist, at 9:20 a.m., there was subsequent radiographic documentation of
 partial treatment of bilateral pneumothorax. The findings on this chest
 radiograph were discussed by Dr. ___ with Dr. ___ ___ Dr. ___, ___ the
 telephone at 9:50 and 9:55 p.m., respectively.
 
 Large bilateral pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, and
 extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and less so right chest wall
 attributable to duodenal perforation.  Since the pneumothorax is bilateral,
 there is less likelihood of mediastinal shift from hemodynamically significant
 positive pleural pressure.  Similarly, although the diaphragm is not
 depressed, there is probably pneumoperitoneum or at least
 pneumoretroperitoneum which could temper the effects of even hemodynamically
 significant elevation of transpleural pressure.
 
 Dr. ___ ___ I discussed these findings and subsequent course of partial
 treatment of the pneumothoraces at 9:30 a.m. on ___, including my concern
 that at least the right pleural drain is substantially if not entirely
 extrathoracic, and that the location of the left pleural drain is dubious as
 well given the failure to evacuate the moderate left pneumothorax after
 improvement with initial placement.
name: pneumothorax

 following series of chest radiographs as late as 8:09 a.m. on ___:
 
 By the time this chest radiograph was officially interpreted by the staff
 radiologist, at 9:20 a.m., there was subsequent radiographic documentation of
 partial treatment of bilateral pneumothorax. The findings on this chest
 radiograph were discussed by Dr. ___ with Dr. ___ ___ Dr. ___, ___ the
 telephone at 9:50 and 9:55 p.m., respectively.
 
 Large bilateral pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, and
 extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and less so right chest wall
 attributable to duodenal perforation.  Since the pneumothorax is bilateral,
 there is less likelihood of mediastinal shift from hemodynamically significant
 positive pleural pressure.  Similarly, although the diaphragm is not
 depressed, there is probably pneumoperitoneum or at least
 pneumoretroperitoneum which could temper the effects of even hemodynamically
 significant elevation of transpleural pressure.
 
 Dr. ___ ___ I discussed these findings and subsequent course of partial
 treatment of the pneumothoraces at 9:30 a.m. on ___, including my concern
 that at least the right pleural drain is substantially if not entirely
 extrathoracic, and that the location of the left pleural drain is dubious as
 well given the failure to evacuate the moderate left pneumothorax after
 improvement with initial placement.
name: pneumothorax

report:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___M with pigtail placed for right pneumothorax, likely
 malpositioned in the liver.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Semi-upright AP view of the chest
 
 COMPARISON:  CT torso ___ at 18:41 chest radiograph ___ at
 18:35
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 There has been interval placement of a right-sided catheter with pigtail
 projecting over the liver.  A persistent moderate size right pneumothorax
 remains with continued leftward shift of mediastinal structures as seen on the
 chest CT scout.  Increased subcutaneous emphysema in the right lateral chest
 wall is noted.  Streaky opacities are noted in the right lung likely
 reflective of atelectasis.  Low lung volumes are present which results in
 crowding of bronchovascular structures and left basilar atelectasis.  Cardiac
 and mediastinal contours otherwise remain unchanged.  Right lateral rib
 fractures are better assessed on the previous CT.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Interval placement of right-sided catheter with pigtail projecting over the
 liver.  Persistent moderate size right pneumothorax with continued mild
 leftward shift of mediastinal structures.  Patchy atelectasis in both lungs. 
 Increased subcutaneous emphysema in the right lateral chest wall.
name: pneumothorax
